Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Integrative Large-Scale Data Analysis and Statistical Inference
Award.AbstractNarration:
Recent technological advancements in data collection and processing have led to the accumulation of vast amount of digital information with various types of auxiliary information such as prior data, external covariates, domain knowledge and expert insights. However, with few analytical tools available, much of the relevant data and auxiliary information have been severely underexploited in most current studies. The analysis of big data with complex structures poses significant challenges and calls for new theory and methodology for information integration. This collaborative research aims to develop new procedures, computational algorithms and statistical software to provide powerful tools for researchers in various scientific fields who routinely collect and analyze high dimensional data, which would help translate dispersed and heterogeneous data sources into new knowledge effectively.

This NSF project aims to develop new principles, theoretical foundations and methodologies for integrative large-scale data analysis and statistical inference. An important theme is to study how to combine the information from multiple sources in a unified framework. The project focuses on four types of problems: (i) inference of two sparse objects; (ii) structured simultaneous inference; (iii) simultaneous set-wise inference and multi-stage inference; and (iv) applications in genomics and network analysis. The new integrative framework provides a powerful approach for extracting and pooling information from various parts of massive data sets, and can improve conventional methods by delivering more accurate, informative and interpretable results.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Summary. Integrative large-scale data analysis is motivated by a range of important applications, where the goal is to effectively incorporate useful structural information and domain knowledge in massive data that are collected routinely in various scientific studies with thousands and even millions of study units/variables. This NSF project develops new methodologies and theory to address four major research goals: (1) We develop an integrative framework for inference of two sparse objects that can handle a wide range of dependence structures such as those arise in multiple testing for high-dimensional linear regression, large covariance/correlation matrices, and Gaussian graphical models. (2) We develop novel theories and methodologies for a class of structured simultaneous inference problems. (3) We develop a general framework for set-wise simultaneous inference and solve related problems such as replicability analysis, simultaneous conjunction tests and multi-stage adaptive testing. (4) We apply the proposed methods to important applications such as the detection of genes-environment interactions, differential gene network analysis and SNP set analysis to address the urgent needs and new challenges arising from important genomics applications. 

Intellectual Merit. While massive and complex data sets being collected routinely in various scientific fields, relevant domain knowledge, including external covariates, scientific insights and prior data, is often available alongside the primary data set. In many settings the data are also known to possess certain intrinsic structures such as sparsity, dependence, groups and hierarchies. It is desirable to incorporate such external and auxiliary information in statistical inference to make more accurate and informative decisions. The analysis of structured data with relevant domain knowledge poses significant challenges and calls for new theory and methodology for information integration in large-scale data analysis and statistical inference. However, with few analytical tools available, much of the relevant data and auxiliary information have been severely underexploited in most current studies. This NSF project develops a new integrative framework that provides a powerful approach for extracting and pooling information from various parts of massive data sets with complex structures. The new inference procedures and analytical tools are shown to improve the power of conventional methods and deliver more informative and interpretable scientific results. The proposed research will make important contributions to multiple testing, simultaneous estimation and statistical decision theories. The methodologies developed in this project can be employed to address important issues from genomics applications. This collaborative research has led to 7 publications in top statistical journals, including a potentially impactful discussion paper in Journal of the Royal Statistical Society, Series B.

Broader Impacts. Integrative large-scale data analysis and statistical inference is an important topic with a wide range of applications in genomics, neuroimaging, astrophysics, climate studies, and signal processing. The research products from this NSF proposal provide new methodologies and technical tools to researchers in various scientific fields who routinely collect and analyze high dimensional data. The PIs’ have collaborated closely with researchers at Harvard School of Public Health and the Perelman School of Medicine at Penn to solve important problems in genomics, including detection of genes-environment interactions, differential gene network analysis and SNP set analysis. We believe that the products from this collaborative research will help translate dispersed and heterogeneous data sources into new knowledge and medical benefits. The procedures and algorithms developed in this project has been implemented as user-friendly and accessible software packages in R and made available on the web along with the associated research reports. In particular, the R-package CARS has been downloaded more than 50,000 times in CRAN in less than two years. This project will also make important contributions to the development of Ph.D. students and postdoctoral fellows. The PIs have given two advanced topics course for Ph. D. students at University of Pennsylvania and University of Southern California on integrative large-scale inference, of which the output of this proposal is an integral part.
